description: e-perfect numbers: numbers n such that the sum of the e-divisors (exponential divisors) of n equals 2n.
comments: The e-divisors (or exponential divisors) of x=Product p(i)^r(i) are all numbers of the form Product p(i)^s(i) where s(i) divides r(i) for all i.The number of e-divisors for n = Product[p_i^e_i] is given by Product[tau(e_i)] (A000005). - _Jon Perry_, Nov 13 2012Conjecture: Every e-perfect number is divisible by 36. - _Jon Perry_, Nov 13 2012
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems In Number Theory, B17.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, e-Perfect Number
example: The e-divisors of 36 are 2*3, 4*3, 2*9 and 4*9 and the sum of these = 2*36, so 36 is e-perfect.
mathematica: ee[n_] := Times @@ (Sum[First[#]^d, {d, Divisors[Last[#]]}] &) /@ FactorInteger[n]; Select[Range[5000], ee[#] == 2 # &] (* _T. D. Noe_, Nov 14 2012 *)
author: _Jud McCranie_, May 29 2000
